question.title: Question
question.description: What is the primary difference between a chalazion and a hordeolum (stye) as seen in the photographs?

option_a.title: Option A
option_a.description: A chalazion is an infection of the eyelid, while a hordeolum is a blockage of the meibomian gland.

option_b.title: Option B
option_b.description: A chalazion is typically painful, whereas a hordeolum is usually painless.

option_c.title: Option C
option_c.description: A chalazion is caused by an infection of the meibomian gland, while a hordeolum is caused by an external staphylococcus bacterial infection.

option_d.title: Option D
option_d.description: A chalazion typically presents as a painless, localized swelling within the eyelid, whereas a hordeolum is a painful, localized swelling at the edge of the eyelid.
